thread.title: John Johnson BC's safety valve
thread.title_full: John Johnson BC's safety valve | Boston Herald

author: Rich Thompson
title: John Johnson BC's safety valve
text:
John Johnson offers a simple summation of his duties as the strong safety on Boston College’s No. 1 rated defense in the country.
“Knowing what you are supposed to know and being a leader out there are the most important parts of being a safety at BC,” said Johnson, a 6-foot, 198-pound junior from West Hyattsville, Md.
Johnson will put those base concepts into motion when the Eagles (3-2, 0-2) host Wake Forest (2-3, 0-2) in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tomorrow at Alumni Stadium.
Johnson is the central nervous system on a defense that tops all FBS schools in total defense (140 yards allowed per game), rushing defense (43.4), passing defense (96.6) and first downs allowed (51).
BC defensive coordinator Don Brown provided a more detailed description of Johnson’s job.
“He has to be a leader because his job is to line us up before every snap, every snap,” said Brown with emphasis. “If he doesn’t make that call, if he doesn’t understand formations, if he doesn’t understand vacant and all that stuff, than I can’t be as creative as I want to be.
“He’s my guy on the field. He’s got to be able to handle it. I’m really proud of him.”
Johnson’s migration from reserve cover corner to the eighth man in the box began with a disciplinary action. Johnson became the Eagles starting boundary corner when Bryce Jones was kicked off the squad on Sept 28, 2014, for violating team rules. He then suffered an arm injury against Clemson on Oct. 18 and missed the last five games of the regular season, returning for the Pinstripe Bowl on Dec. 27.
“Last year was a real difficult loss when he went down against Clemson and missed those last few games,” said Brown. “When guys that are trained corners move to safety they have coverage skills and that makes you secondary better in the long run.”
BC free safety Justin Simmons helped Johnson make the transition.
“The safety and the corner work together a lot so just witnessing what he (cornerback) is doing and doing well, that makes doing my job at the same time much easier,” said Johnson. “That made it and easy transition but safety means being more of a tackler.”
Johnson started five games and has 18 tackles with half sack, an interception and a forced fumble. The BC front seven has been so effective against the run that there are few leftovers for Johnson and Simmons to clean up.
The Eagles held Florida State preseason All-American Dalvin Cook, who was averaging 211 yards per game, to 54 yards on 15 carries.
“I love working with that front seven because it’s the best in the country, I believe,” said Johnson. “Usually they do their job really well but if something leaks out it is our job to get the guy on the ground.”
